page.title: 08The Church in Risby
page.content: St. Giles church is of flint construction with a fine example of a pre-Saxon round tower. The scratchdial on the tower is possibly seventeenth century. The interior of the church reflects many of the changes that have occurred within the ecclesiastical buildings throughout the Suffolk area over the last nine hundred years. There are still examples of the twelfth century wall paintings, which though faded are still attractive. The stone font, possibly dating from the fifteenth century, shows evidence of having been plastered over to hide the ornamentation, probably in the seventeenth century. The church contains a finely carved wooden rood screen and a door to the now defunct rood loft.
